title-group.article-title: High-performance CeFeCo/FeSiAl soft magnetic composites for megahertz power devices

contrib-group.aff: 1School of Materials Science and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Silicon and Advanced Semiconductor Materials, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China
2Shanxi-Zheda Institute of Advanced Materials and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan 030032, China
3Key Laboratory of Rare Earths, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ganzhou 341000, China

author-notes.corresp: a)Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed: chen_wu@zju.edu.cn and mse_yanmi@zju.edu.cn

license.license-p: All article content, except where otherwise noted, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC BY) license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/).

abstract.p: Soft magnetic composites (SMCs) play a crucial role in modern electronics and electrical devices, for which challenges remain in maintaining magnetic performance and reducing loss at megahertz (MHz) frequencies. Here, CeFeCo/FeSiAl@ polyurethane (PU) SMCs have been rationally designed with the simultaneous achievement of large relative permeability, high domain-wall resonance frequency, and low power loss. As a rare-earth soft magnetic alloy, the CeFeCo is promising for high-frequency applications due to its easy-plane anisotropy, whereas FeSiAl is advantageous with increased electrical resistivity as well as approaching-zero magnetocrystalline anisotropy and magnetostriction. Hot pressing has been adopted to achieve a dense and homogeneous distribution of CeFeCo and FeSiAl powders in the PU for reduced magnetic dilution and eddy current loss. The resultant SMCs exhibit optional soft magnetic performance with large relative permeability of 21.0, low power loss of 3677.5 kW·m−3 at 5 MHz, and high domain-wall resonance frequency of 386.1 MHz. As such this work provides insights into the design of high-frequency SMCs incorporating novel rare-earth soft magnetic alloys.

funding-source.named-content: National Key Research and Development Program of China
Shanxi-Zheda Institute of Advanced Materials and Chemical Engineering
Space Application System of China Manned Space Program
Key Research and Development Program of Zhejiang Province
Opening Fund of Key Laboratory of Rare Earth, Chinese Academy of Sciences
National Natural Science Foundation of China

sec.label: I.
sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Soft magnetic composites (SMCs) with large permeability and low power loss at high working frequencies are technologically important for electronic devices.1–3 Especially, recent advances in third-generation semiconductors, i.e., SiC and GaN, urgently demand the development of soft magnetic materials in the Megahertz (MHz) range.1,4 The prevailing SMCs, including Fe,5,6 FeSi,7,8 FeSiAl,2,9 and FeSiCr,10,11 however, encounter enormous challenges at such high frequencies. On the one hand, increased frequency leads to rapidly deteriorated permeability due to the domain-wall resonance.12,13 On the other hand, since the eddy current loss is proportional to the square of the frequency, the overall loss surges with raised frequency.14

To tackle the magnetic deterioration at high frequencies, many efforts have been attempted, but it remains challenging to increase domain-wall resonance frequency (fd). Recently, rare-earth soft magnetic alloys, mainly involving the rhombohedral 2:17-type15,16 and the tetragonal 2:14:1-type17 crystalline structures, have come into focus as promising high-frequency soft magnetic materials. Categories exhibit an easy-magnetization plane giving rise to confined planar domain-wall movement and enhanced fd.18–20 For instance, Wang et al.13 prepared Ce2Fe17N3−δ rare-earth soft magnetic alloys by atmospheric nitrogenating, resulting in an improved fd of 700.0 MHz compared to cubic α-Fe with fd of 200.0 MHz.12 Despite the significantly increased domain-wall resonance frequency for the rare-earth soft magnetic materials, it remains challenging for practical applicability due to their low intrinsic permeability.

Insulation coating technology employs high-resistance materials to wrap magnetic powders to reduce eddy current loss. Typical strategies to form the insulation coatings can be classified into two categories, depending on whether the alloy element of the magnetic powders is involved in the reaction. The in situ coating methods may include surface oxidation,9,21 nitridation,22 and phosphorization.23 Although such routes exhibit stronger adhesion, they are only applicable to a few types of magnetic powders and the coatings tend to crack or decompose in the subsequent high-pressure compaction (up to 2 GPa) and stress-relieving heat treatment (>500 °C).24 Alternatively, reactions without the incorporation of the alloy element provide a versatile insulation route. For instance, high-resistance oxides, such as ferrites,25–27 SiO2,28 Al2O3,9 and MgO,29 have been fabricated surrounding the magnetic powders by sol–gel reactions, giving rise to tailorable coating layers but deteriorated mechanical properties, hindering the formation of the densely packed structure during compaction. Consequently, developing advanced insulation coating technology compatible with subsequential preparation procedures demands further investigation.

In this work, high-performance SMCs have been designed by combining the CeFeCo with high domain-wall resonance frequency, FeSiAl with large permeability, and polyurethane (PU) with strong insulation. Hot pressing has also been adopted to eliminate the requirement of complex stress-relieving procedures to avoid their impact. Microstructures, magnetic properties, and loss mechanisms of the SMCs have been systematically analyzed. The resultant CeFeCo/FeSiAl@PU SMCs exhibit large permeability, high domain-wall resonance frequency, and low power loss due to the synergistic component effects, providing a potential design strategy for the SMCs operating in high-frequency ranges.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The FeSiAl powders were provided by Changsha Tijo Metal Materials Co., Ltd., China. The CeFeCo powders were fabricated with high-purity Ce, Fe, and Co (99.99 wt. %) obtained from Beijing Dream Materials Technology Co., Ltd., China as the raw materials. The PU powders (Elastollan 1195A) were supplied by BASF Co., Ltd., China. All reagents were utilized as-received without any additional purification steps.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Synthesis of the CeFeCo powders
sec.p: The CeFeCo alloy was synthesized using a melting-annealing-quenching technique, with an optimal atomic ratio of Ce2(Fe0.8Co0.2)17 based on previous work.30 Additional 10 wt. % Ce was incorporated to compensate for the loss of Ce due to evaporation and surface oxidation. Typically, the Ce (7.46 g), Fe (18.37 g), and Co (4.85 g) were melted together to form a liquid alloy, following cooling under an argon atmosphere. The resultant ingot underwent subsequent annealing in vacuum at 1000 °C for 100 h, followed by quenching in cold water. The CeFeCo powders (<0.2 mm) were obtained by grinding and sieving. Planetary ball milling (250 r/min, 4 h) was employed to further reduce particle size with the addition of CeFeCo and ZrO2 balls (mass ratio of 1:20) as well as simethicone (0.2 g) and n-hexane (100 ml) in an agate tank, followed by vacuum drying at 50 °C.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Fabrication of the CeFeCo/FeSiAl SMCs
sec.p: Varying mass fractions of CeFeCo (0, 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 wt. %) were mixed with FeSiAl powders in acetone under ultrasonic treatment for 30 min and, respectively, denoted as FSA, 10CFC90FSA, 20CFC80FSA, 30CFC70FSA, 40CFC60FSA, and 50CFC50FSA. Subsequently, the mixed powders were dissolved with PU at a filling volume of 65%. The mixture was stirred under ultrasonic treatment until complete evaporation of the acetone solution. Finally, the resultant mixture was placed in a toroidal die with an outer diameter of 12.0 mm and an inner diameter of 6.0 mm, and molded under a temperature of 90 °C and a pressure of 300 MPa for 10 min.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Characterization and performance evaluation
sec.p: X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker-D8 ADVANCE) with the Co Kα radiation (λ = 1.7902 Å) was used to identify crystalline phases. The morphology and elemental distribution were observed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-IT800) equipped with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The resistivity of the samples was measured using the four-probe method (RTS-9). The hysteresis loops were recorded were measured by a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID, Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5). To determine the coercivity values, the M–H curves were measured with a step interval of 2 Oe within the range of ±40 Oe. Complex permeability from 1 MHz to 1 GHz was obtained using an impedance analyzer (Agilent E4991A).31 B–H analyzer (IWATSU SY-8218) was adopted to measure power loss from 100 kHz to 5 MHz under 10 mT32 (the testing methodology was extensively explicated in the supplementary material).

sec.label: III.
sec.title: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
Figures 1(a) and 1(b) show the SEM images of the FeSiAl and the as-milled CeFeCo powders with insets illustrating their size distributions. Both FeSiAl and CeFeCo powders exhibit irregular rock-like morphology and uniform powder distributions with average sizes around 60.86 ± 23.61 µm and 3.62 ± 1.24 µm, respectively. The XRD results of CeFeCo and FeSiAl powders are shown in Fig. 1(c), where the diffraction peaks at 35.05°, 36.30°, 42.85°, 44.20°, 50.15°, 51.10°, 56.50°, 73.45°, and 74.20° are attributed to the (113), (104), (300), (024), (303), (214), (223), (413), and (324) planes, respectively, of the rhombohedral Th2Zn17-type crystal structure of CeFeCo phase (space group R
3
̄
m) and the diffraction peaks at 31.55°, 36.60°, 52.75°, and 77.90° correspond to (111), (200), (220), and (400) planes, respectively, of the face-centered cubic crystal structure of FeSiAl (space group Fm
3
̄
m). All XRD peaks of CeFeCo shift to a higher angle by ∼0.1°–0.2° as compared to those of the standard Ce2Fe17 spectrum (PDF No. 48–1455) due to the incorporation of Co to substitute the Fe in the Ce2Fe17 lattice.33 Figure 1(d) shows the XRD patterns taken from the composites where enhanced peak intensity of CeFeCo is observed, indicating its increased weight ratio with the largest CeFeCo content obtained in the 50CFC50FSA.

caption.p: SEM images and size distributions of the (a) FeSiAl and (b) CeFeCo powders. XRD patterns taken from the (c) FeSiAl and CeFeCo powders as well as the (d) CeFeCo/FeSiAl composites with varied CeFeCo content.

sec.p: To assess the distribution of the powders in the SMCs, cross-sectional morphology and elemental distribution have been examined. All the samples exhibit similar insulation coating as shown in Figs. S1–S5 in the supplementary material, among which the results of 20CFC80FSA as a representative sample are shown in Fig. 2. Small powders tend to fill the gaps in between larger ones as shown in Fig. 2(a), which is shown further enlarged in Fig. 2(b), indicating a high level of density within the SMC. Figures 2(c)–2(i) provide the EDS information on elemental distribution, where Fe, Si, and Al are primarily concentrated within the larger powders while the Ce and Co distribute between their gaps. C and O elements also predominantly distribute in the gaps between the large magnetic powders. These observations suggest that the FeSiAl powders are wrapped by the PU, whereas numerous micrometer-sized CeFeCo powders are dispersed in between.

caption.p: Cross-sectional SEM image of (a) the 20CFC80FSA with enlargement shown in (b). EDS mapping showing the elemental distribution of (c) Fe, (d) Si, (e) Al, (f) Ce, (g) Co, (h) C, and (i) O.

sec.p: Figure 3(a) presents the magnetization curves of composites with varied contents of CeFeCo, for which detailed values of saturation magnetization (Ms) and coercivity (Hc) are summarized in Fig. 3(b). The Ms of CeFeCo/FeSiAl composites demonstrates a gradual increment from 116.87 to 121.79 emu/g as the CeFeCo content increases from 10 to 50 wt. %. Such increment in Ms can be attributed to the higher Ms values of the CeFeCo powders compared to FeSiAl.33 The Hc also increases from 1.97 to 32.06 Oe. Fig. S6 presents the magnetization curves of CeFeCo SMCs, for which the Hc is 52.73 Oe. The large coercivity of CeFeCo can be attributed to its higher magnetocrystalline anisotropy and magnetostriction than FeSiAl as well as the large amount of residual stress introduced by ball milling,13 which hinder the domain wall movements. Consequently, the addition of CeFeCo powders gives rise to increased Hc.

caption.p: (a) Hysteresis loops of CeFeCo composites with various FeSiAl contents at room temperature and (b) the extracted Ms and Hc.

sec.p: To investigate the high-frequency properties of the CeFeCo/FeSiAl SMCs, complex permeability spectra have been measured as shown in Figs. 4(a) and 4(b). With raised CeFeCo content, the real part of the permeability of the SMCs initially increases followed by a decrease. The initial increment of permeability can be attributed to the interstice filling effect34 between FeSiAl and CeFeCo powders with different average particle sizes in the formation of the denser composite structure. Further increased CeFeCo, however, leads to a lower permeability due to the dilution effect of the CeFeCo with smaller permeability compared to the FeSiAl. Figure 4(c) shows the real permeability at 1 MHz and domain-wall resonance frequency where enhanced initial permeability has been achieved for the 10CFC90FSA. The domain-wall resonance frequency fd significantly increases from 181.2 MHz (FSA) to 630.8 MHz (50CFC50FSA) with increased CeFeCo (Fig. S7), demonstrating the effectiveness of incorporating CeFeCo for higher frequency applications.

caption.p: High-frequency properties of CeFeCo composites with various FeSiAl contents: (a) the real permeability spectra, (b) the imaginary permeability spectra, (c) the real permeability at 1 MHz, and domain-wall resonance frequency (fd).

sec.p: Power loss (Pcv) is a crucial parameter for evaluating the high-frequency performance of SMCs. Figure 5(a) presents the Pcv of the SMCs with varying mass fractions of CeFeCo, which increases rapidly with raised applied field frequency. At 5 MHz, increased CeFeCo concentration initially gives rise to a decrement of Pcv followed by Pcv increasing again with a minimum power loss achieved (3677.5 kW/m3) for the 20CFC80FSA. It is worth noting that all composite SMCs exhibit smaller Pcv than that of the FSA, indicating significant contribution of CeFeCo for reducing power loss.

caption.p: (a) Power loss of the SMCs with different CeFeCo contents and its separation into the (b) Ph, (c) Pe, and (d) Pr components.

sec.p:
The power loss can be separated into hysteresis loss (Ph), eddy-current loss (Pe), and residual loss (Pr) as follows:12,35

, (1)where kh, ke, and kr represent the hysteresis, current, and residual coefficients, respectively. The α represents the simulation coefficient, which usually depends on the intrinsic properties of the material. The x and y represent the coefficients related to the applied magnetic field and frequency, respectively.

The Pr is due to magnetic after-effects, magnetic resonance, and size resonance effects, which generally become significant at frequencies above 1 MHz. In the frequency range below 500 kHz used in this study, these effects can be considered negligible.12,35–38 Consequently, the coefficients of hysteresis loss (Kh) and eddy-current loss (Ke) can be approximated as the intercept and slope of the Pcv/f-f plot according to

Table I gives the Kh and Ke from 100 to 500 kHz obtained by fitting the Pcv/f-f plots where a larger R-square indicates a higher reliability of fitting results based on Eq. (2). Figure S9 presents both the Pcv measured experimentally and the Ph + Pe obtained through fitting. The close numerical similarity between these values also supports the validity of neglecting residual losses below 500 kHz.

caption.p: Coefficients of each term and formulas with different CeFeCo mass fractions.

sec.p:
The Ph and Pe are further obtained based on Ph = f · Kh and Ph = f2 · Ke as shown in Figs. 5(b) and 5(c). The Ph increases from 990.5 kW m−3 (FSA) to 1615.0 kW m−3 (50CFC50FSA) with raised CeFeCo content. In general, the Ph mainly depends on Hc. The addition of CeFeCo powders leads to increased Hc in the SMCs [Fig. 3(b)] and resultant increased Ph. The Pe significantly decrease from 3194.1 kW m−3 (FSA) to 2365.2 kW m−3 (50CFC50FSA) with increased CeFeCo. For the SMCs, two distinct types of eddy current loss exist including the inter-particle eddy current loss throughout the entire magnet and the intra-particle eddy current loss, which is associated with eddy current flow within individual magnetic powder. Such two forms of eddy current loss can be expressed as follows:38–40

The deff, d, and D represent the effective eddy current dimension, particle size, and average size of the eddy current loop, respectively. The ρs, ρp, and ρ represent the grain boundary resistivity, particle resistivity, and bulk resistivity, respectively, the β1 and β2 are the geometric factors, and the C is the proportionality constant. Equation (3) demonstrates that the eddy current loss is directly proportional to the square of the magnetic powder diameter and inversely proportional to the resistivity of SMCs. Hence, careful consideration of the particle size and resistivity is essential to minimize the eddy current loss in practical terms. Figure S8 illustrates the constantly decreasing bulk resistivity (ρ) from 4715.5 to 1035.9 Ω·cm for the SMCs with raised CeFeCo content. This may arise from the dispersion of small CeFeCo powders within the PU, leading to a decline in the insulation performance of the PU and subsequently reduces the bulk resistivity.41 The change of the ρ trend, however, is contradicted by the variation observed in the Pe for the CeFeCo/FeSiAl SMCs. According to Eq. (3), the Pe is also proportional to the square of average size D2. The introduction of smaller CeFeCo powders, compared to larger FeSiAl powders, significantly reduces both inter-particle and intra-particle eddy current paths due to their reduced particle size [Fig. 1(b)]. Consequently, the impact of the particle size outweighs the increase caused by resistivity, resulting in a decrease in Pe as the CeFeCo content in SMCs increases.

When the frequency exceeds 500 kHz, the residual loss, including size resonance, domain-wall resonance, natural resonance, etc., becomes non-neglectable.12,35 For SMCs, the testing frequency is mostly less than 500 kHz;9,37,38 thus, there is very little calculation of residual losses. However, for ferrites, the testing frequency is in the MHz range, and there is a wealth of calculations on residual losses.42–44 Birčáková et al.45 have demonstrated that the calculation method of the residual loss for ferrite is also applicable to the SMCs in the MHz frequency range. Consequently, the Pr here can be identified from the non-linear region of the Pcv/f-f plots based on the following equation:

Figure 5(d) shows the evolution of the Pr that significantly decreases from 541.9 kW m−3 (FSA) to 212.3 kW m−3 (50CFC50FSA) with increased CeFeCo at 5 MHz. The Pr in the MHz frequency range originates from the domain-wall resonance. Consequently, a lower resonance frequency in the FSA SMC [Fig. 4(c)] gives rise to the highest Pr. With increased incorporation of the CFC, the Pr monotonically decreases due to the significantly raised relaxation frequency of the easy-plane rare-earth component.12,46

Based the above analyses, it can be found that the rational addition of small CeFeCo powders contributes to reduce eddy current paths and effectively suppress eddy current loss. Furthermore, higher domain-wall resonance frequency can be achieved with the incorporation of the CeFeCo, giving rise to significantly reduced residual loss in the MHz frequency. However, excessive incorporation of CeFeCo leads to deterioration of coercivity and rapid increment in the hysteresis loss. Based on the comprehensive effects of the Ph, Pe, and Pr, the minimum power loss of 3677.5 kW m−3 (5 MHz, 10 mT) can be achieved for the 20CFC80FSA with CeFeCo content of 20 wt. %.

Table II gives the comparison of the performance of the 20CFC80FSA sample with related SMCs in the literature. The FeSiAl/CeFeCo SMCs in this work demonstrate the lowest losses across a wide frequency range from 25 kHz to 5 MHz. Moreover, the CeFeCo/FeSiAl SMCs offer notable enhancement in the domain-wall resonance frequency compared to their traditional counterparts due to the incorporation of the easy-plane rare-earth component.

caption.p: Comparison of previously reported soft magnetic material properties and this work.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In summary, FeSiAl/CeFeCo SMCs with large permeability, high domain-wall resonance frequency, and low power loss for MHz frequency applications have been fabricated by hot-pressing FeSiAl and CeFeCo magnetic powders with PU. Benefiting from synergistic component design and processing strategy, the 20CFC80FSA with 20 wt. % CeFeCo exhibits the optimal soft magnetic performance with minimum power loss (3677.5 kW m−3 under 5 MHz, 10 mT) and high domain-wall resonance frequency (386.1 MHz). Thus, this work not only sheds light on the fabrication of high-frequency and low-loss FeSiAl/CeFeCo SMCs but also advances the insight of compositional design for rare-earth-based SMCs employed in MHz power devices.
